Description: Large scarab carved from steatite; stylised back with clypeus and prothorax simply indicated with T- shape lines, winglets shown as loops (not normal triangles or V-incisions); feathering on front legs indicated boldly with parallel lines; underside incised with motif arranged vertically; in upper register, plumed oval inscribed with Menkheperra name, flanked by facing uraei; in lower register, scarab flanked by bread loaves, surmounting a neb-basket sign; pierced lengthwise; yellowish smooth shiny surface, from the glaze.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Jaeger, the motif of the underside is unique (Jaeger 1982, 89, § 386). A relatively similar composition, with a hes vase replacing the Menkheperra cartouche, is provided by a scarab found in Naukratis in 1899 by Hogarth (Cairo, Egyptian Museum CG37369) and another one in Ibiza (the latter discussed in Gorton 1996, Type V, nos 2 and 5). Gorton consider this scarab to be either a genuine Hyksos-style scarab or a late imitation of this style (Gorton 1996, 18). A Hyksos date is too early, though early scarabs were discovered in Naukratis (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). A 26th dynasty date is more probable.
